entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 24 at 9:28AM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
At 927 AM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near West, or 13 miles southeast of Hillsboro, moving northeast at 60 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and nickel size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
This strong thunderstorm will be near... Navarro Mills Lake around 940 AM CST. Dawson around 945 AM CST.
Other locations impacted by this storm include Malone, Birome, Dresden, Elm Mott, Mertens, Tours, Mount Calm, Irene, Frost, and Tehuacana.
This includes Interstate 35 between mile markers 341 and 360.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hill; Navarro; McLennan; Limestone

cap:parameter.value: A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of northeastern McLennan, northwestern Limestone, southeastern Hill and southwestern Navarro Counties through 1000 AM CST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 24 at 9:27AM CST by NWS Little Rock AR
entry.summary:
At 927 AM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Richwoods, or near Arkadelphia, moving northeast at 50 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Arkadelphia... Malvern... Gurdon... Rockport... Caddo Valley... Poyen... Perla... Whelen Springs... Beirne... Gum Springs in Clark County... Richwoods... Jenkins Ferry State Park... Donaldson... Friendship... Magnet Cove... Lono... Curtis... Gifford... Dalark... Midway in Hot Spring County...
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clark; Hot Spring; Grant; Dallas

cap:parameter.value: A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of central Clark, west central Grant, northwestern Dallas and eastern Hot Spring Counties through 1015 AM CST

entry.title: Flood Watch issued November 24 at 9:14AM CST until November 24 at 3:00PM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of north central and northeast Texas, including the following counties, in north central Texas, Collin, Dallas, Denton, Fannin, Grayson, Hunt, Rockwall and Tarrant. In northeast Texas, Delta, Hopkins, Lamar and Rains.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM CST this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor-drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Residual runoff within the Metroplex and rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches, with isolated higher amounts up to 3 inches east of I-35.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Grayson; Fannin; Lamar; Denton; Collin; Hunt; Delta; Hopkins; Tarrant; Dallas; Rockwall; Rains

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CST THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 24 at 9:10AM CST by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
At 910 AM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a line of strong thunderstorms extending from 27 miles northeast of Blevins to near Oil City, or extending from 29 miles north of Prescott to 23 miles north of Shreveport, moving east at 45 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and half inch size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Magnolia, Hope, Springhill, Prescott, Stamps, Waldo, Lewisville, McNeil, Vivian, Cullen, Plain Dealing, Cotton Valley, Oil City, Sarepta, Bradley, Taylor, Emmet, Emerson, Hosston and Buckner.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hempstead; Nevada; Miller; Lafayette; Columbia; Caddo; Bossier; Webster; Marion

entry.title: Flood Warning issued November 24 at 8:53AM CST until November 25 at 4:40AM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Fort Worth TX has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Texas...
Denton Creek Near Justin affecting Denton County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Denton Creek near Justin.
* WHEN...Until late tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Minor out of bank flooding will occur to farm and ranch lands near the creek.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 AM CST Monday the stage was 8.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning to a crest of 10.7 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late this afternoon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Denton, TX

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TONIGHT

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued November 24 at 8:49AM CST until November 24 at 10:15AM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
FFWFWD
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Southern Dallas County in north central Texas... Northwestern Ellis County in north central Texas...
* Until 1015 AM CST.
* At 849 AM CST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are forecast. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges.
IMPACT...Flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets, and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Dallas, Grand Prairie, Mesquite, Mansfield, Desoto, Cedar Hill, Duncanville, Lancaster, Waxahachie, Balch Springs, Ennis, Midlothian, Seagoville, Glenn Heights, Red Oak, Hutchins, Cockrell Hill, Sunnyvale, Wilmer and Ovilla.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dallas, TX; Ellis, TX

entry.title: Flood Warning issued November 24 at 7:59AM CST until November 26 at 1:09AM CST by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Fort Worth TX has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Texas...
Trinity River At Dallas affecting Dallas County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Trinity River at Dallas.
* WHEN...From this evening to early Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 33.0 feet, Minor flooding along the river is expected. Bike trails along the river will have floodwaters several feet deep, and the parking lot of Trammel Crow Park beneath the Sylvan bridge will flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:30 AM CST Monday the stage was 17.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 30.0 feet. - Flood stage is 30.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this evening to a crest of 33.1 feet late tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dallas, TX

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 24 at 6:54AM CST by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary: Area observations and webcams indicate that fog has spread into southern Ford County approaching 7 AM. It's unclear how quickly the fog will spread north, or how widespread dense fog will become, but based on recent webcam imagery from Gibson City, expect to encounter at least localized visibility of one quarter mile or less in dense fog, particularly near and south of US Highway 24 through mid morning. Motorists are advised to reduce speed, keep a safe following distance, and use low beams when driving in dense fog.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Livingston; Iroquois; Ford

cap:parameter.value: Patchy Dense Fog in Parts of Central Illinois this Morning

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 24 at 4:47AM PST until November 24 at 10:00PM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents. Breaking waves of 13 to 18 feet are expected.
* WHERE...Pacific Coast beaches.
* WHEN...Through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 24 at 5:32AM MST by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
Strong westerly winds, with gusts of between 45 to 55 mph, will occur from the late morning through late afternoon hours today; with even the potential for isolated higher gusts in wind prone areas, especially between 1 PM and 5 PM MST this afternoon.
Travelers should be prepared for strong cross winds. Know your vehicles limits!
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Blackfoot and MacDonald Pass; Gates of the Mountains; Helena Valley; Elkhorn and Boulder Mountains; Canyon Ferry Area

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 24 at 2:15AM PST until November 24 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.
* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South Washington Coast.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM PST this morning.
* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or drowning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM PST THIS MORNING

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 24 at 12:54AM AKST until November 24 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...ACCUMULATING SNOW FOR HAINES MONDAY...
A weak, decaying low pressure will bring moisture up from the south, generating snow showers for Haines, Lutak, and Mud Bay beginning early Monday morning, continuing through Monday afternoon. Highest uncertainty regarding this system is the depth of the moisture profile, which will dictate heavier rates. As of 1230am, with slightly quicker arrival of the precipitation, adjusted timing of the advisory forward a couple hours. Otherwise, no major changes to ongoing forecast. Previously toned down the advisory amounts, but there is still potential for rates exceeding 0.5 inches, around 40% through Monday morning.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 5 inches.
* WHERE...Haines, Lutak, and Mud Bay.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM AKST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...As of 12:30am AKST, an estimated 1" of snow has fallen via satellite imagery and AKDOT 511 webcams near the Chilkat River Bridge. Further towards town, Haines Airport is reporting snowfall with reduced visibilities as low as 4 statute miles. Snowfall is expected to continue through Monday, heaviest snowfall rates are expected Monday morning, with rates possibly exceeding 0.5 inches per hour at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Haines Borough and Klukwan

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued November 24 at 3:21AM CST until November 25 at 12:00PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:

* WHERE...Northwest and north central North Dakota.
* WHEN...From this evening through Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued November 24 at 1:42AM CST until November 26 at 6:00AM CST by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN
entry.summary:
...RAIN WILL TRANSITION TO SNOW TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING, WITH ACCUMULATING SNOW FALLING THROUGH WEDNESDAY MORNING. GUSTY WINDS ALONGSIDE FALLING SNOW WILL LEAD TO REDUCED VISIBILITY DUE TO BLOWING SNOW...
.A potent upper level wave will move across the area on Tuesday, with rain initially becoming snow as the lower atmosphere cools underneath strengthening forcing for ascent. Rain early on will transition to snow generally from west to east as the atmosphere cools, becoming all snow by Tuesday evening. Snow rates could exceed 0.5 inches per hour at times leading to quick accumulations favoring central Minnesota.
Winds will increase as the system moves through, with gusts as high as 35-40mph late Tuesday into early Wednesday leading to reduced visibility and blowing snow.
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations between 2 and 4 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Todd, Douglas, Pope, and Stevens Counties.
* WHEN...From late Tuesday morning through late Tuesday night.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning and evening commutes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Douglas; Todd; Stevens; Pope

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH LATE TUESDAY NIGHT

* WHERE...East facing reefs of the Marianas.
* WHEN...Through late Wednesday night.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Elevated easterly trade swell is expected to persist through midweek, maintaining a high risk of rip currents along east facing reefs of the Marianas through Wednesday night. Swell and associated surf is expected to diminish through the second half of the week, which may allow the high rip current risk to fall to moderate by Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guam; Rota; Tinian; Saipan

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued November 24 at 2:30PM ChST until November 25 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 7 to 9 feet.
* WHERE...North facing reefs of Pohnpei.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM ChST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A trade-wind surge has resulted in an increased northeast trade swell. This swell, combined with a small, but long period north swell, will produce hazardous surf conditions along north facing reefs.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Pohnpei

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CHST TUESDAY

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued November 23 at 7:20PM PST until November 24 at 11:00AM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in dense fog.
* WHERE...Carquinez Strait and Delta, Central Sacramento Valley, Northern San Joaquin Valley, and Southern Sacramento Valley.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM PST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Sacramento Valley; Southern Sacramento Valley; Carquinez Strait and Delta; Northern San Joaquin Valley

cap:parameter.value: DENSE FOG ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM PST MONDAY

entry.title: Flood Watch issued November 23 at 7:14PM CST until November 25 at 12:00AM CST by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Portions of southwest Arkansas, including the following counties, Hempstead, Howard, Lafayette, Little River, Miller, Nevada and Sevier, southeast Oklahoma, including the following county, McCurtain, and northeast Texas, including the following counties, Bowie, Camp, Cass, Franklin, Morris, Red River and Titus.
* WHEN...From 6 AM CST Monday through Monday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Excessive, heavy rainfall of near 1-3 inches with isolated higher amounts will be possible during the day Monday through Monday Evening.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Sevier; Howard; Little River; Hempstead; Nevada; Miller; Lafayette; McCurtain; Red River; Bowie; Franklin; Titus; Camp; Morris; Cass

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM CST MONDAY THROUGH MONDAY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 23 at 8:11PM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
..Patchy Dense Fog Possible Tonight into Monday Morning...
Patchy dense fog may reduce visibility down to around one quarter of a mile tonight into mid-morning Monday. If traveling, be alert for potential rapid changes in visibility. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.

* WHERE...Portions of south central Indiana and east central, north central, northwest, and south central Kentucky.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 23 at 11:11AM MST until November 24 at 11:00PM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. There is a likelihood of moderate to isolated major winter weather impacts. Total snow accumulations between 2 to 6 inches in the valleys and 6 to 18 inches in the higher terrain including Marias Pass. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Polebridge, Highway 83 Bigfork to Swan Lake, Glacier National Park, Marias Pass, Bad Rock Canyon, and Essex.
* WHEN...From 11 PM this evening to 11 PM MST Monday.
* IMPACTS...For MODERATE winter weather impacts, expect disruptions to normal activities. Hazardous traveling conditions. Use extra caution while driving. Closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur.
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Glacier Region

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 PM THIS EVENING TO 11 PM MST MONDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 23 at 11:11AM MST until November 24 at 12:00PM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. There is a likelihood of minor to moderate winter weather impacts. Total snow accumulations up to 2 inches in the valleys and 2 to 6 inches in the higher terrain including Lolo and Lost Trail passes. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Highway 93 Sula to Lost Trail Pass, Highway 12 Powell to Lolo Pass, Lolo Pass, and Dixie.
* WHEN...From 11 PM MST /10 PM PST/ this evening to noon MST /11 AM PST/ Monday.
* IMPACTS...For MODERATE winter weather impacts, expect disruptions to normal activities. Hazardous traveling conditions. Use extra caution while driving. Closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning commute, especially over higher passes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Clearwater Mountains; Bitterroot/Sapphire Mountains

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 11 PM MST /10 PM PST/ THIS EVENING TO NOON MST /11 AM PST/ MONDAY
